title: Organization
body: This course guide will give you an overview of the learning goals, structure and organisation of the course and the different types of learning material and techniques you will encounter during the course.
pageBody: This course guide will give you an overview of the learning goals, structure and organisation of the course and the different types of learning material and techniques you will encounter during the course.

title: Lecture L02
body:
This lecture is about

  • defining what is relevant for the system - system context
  • establishing the scope of the system - system boundary
  • realizing that wrong system context leads to erroneous requirements - accuracy
pageBody: Welcome to the second lecture of our Requirements Engineering course, in which we comprehensively explore the critical elements that define software systems, their surroundings, and the diverse requirements that govern their existence.

title: Lecture L12
body:
This lecture is about

  • analysing and understanding the relations among requirements, requirements sources, and development artefacts
  • supporting other activities, especially useful for maintenance
  • the challenges of maintaining good traceability and how tool support can assist
pageBody: Imagine the traceability process, like connecting the dots in a big picture. It's a way to show how different parts of a project link together.

title: Lecture L11
body:
This lecture is about

  • managing requirements of complex projects
  • how requirements can change throughout a project
  • how changes need to be structured and processed
  • handling change requests require a process on its own
pageBody: Change management in the Requirements Engineering (RE) process involves modifying or updating the initially defined requirements.

title: Lecture L05
body:
This lecture is about 

  • gaining a shared understanding of requirements
  • resolving conflicts between stakeholders
  • achieving a unified and agreed-upon understanding of requirements among all stakeholders after negotiation
pageBody: The second phase of the requirements engineering process is negotiation. In Requirements Engineering (RE), negotiation refers to collaboratively and iteratively discussing, clarifying, and refining requirements with various stakeholders to reach a consensus on what a software system or product should accomplish.

title: Lecture 07
body:
This lecture is about

  • exploring the context-dependent necessity of requirements documentation
  •  using natural language for requirements documentation
  • defining a fixed structure for the documentation using Syntactic Requirements Patterns
pageBody: Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. We will have four full lectures (L06 - L09) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, its different steps, and the tools and models available to help you during this process.

title: Lecture L01
body:
This lecture is about

  • exploring how Requirement Engineering is crucial for project success
  • how bad requirements can jeopardize projects
  • how Requirement Engineering goes beyond merely "getting the requirements and writing them down."
pageBody: In this lecture, you will find out why Requirements Engineering (RE) is essential for software and systems engineers, get an overview of what it is, and learn the different steps of the process.

title: Lecture L03
body:
This lecture is about

  • exploring the role of elicitation in ensuring accurate requirements
  • identifying stakeholders, documents and existing systems as requirement sources
  • selecting and combining various elicitation techniques for optimal results
pageBody: Requirements Elicitation is the initial process of gathering, defining, and documenting stakeholders' needs, expectations, and constraints for a software system or project. It is a crucial aspect of practical requirements management within the broader context of software development or project management.

title: Lecture L04
body:
The lecture is about

  • identifying steps in planning requirement elicitation
  • capturing requirements by identifying essential sources and combining appropriate techniques
pageBody: In the first part of the lecture on requirements elicitation, we covered why this is an essential step of the RE process and introduced some techniques. Now, we will cover some additional practices and summarise the critical points.

title: Lecture L06
body:
This lecture is about

  • exploring different types of documentation, including natural languages, conceptual models, and hybrid approaches
  • analyzing different perspectives like data, functions, and behavioural
  • providing means to standardized structure for requirement documents
pageBody: Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. We will have four lectures (L06 - L09) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, its different steps, and the tools and models available to help you during this process.

title: Lecture 08
body:
This lecture is about:

  • exploring conceptual models for requirements documentation, balancing abstraction and overview with learning a modelling language while ensuring the model fits its purpose.
  • making use of the versatility of UML in modelling and other alternative approaches.
pageBody: Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. We will have four lectures (L06 - L09) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, its different steps, and the tools and models available to help you during this process.

title: Lecture L10
body:
This lecture is about

  • ensuring the quality of the requirements through validation
  • making sure that all stakeholders are on the same page
  • exploring the different aspects of quality and the six principles of validation
  • checking the different techniques available for validation
pageBody: Requirements validation is like ensuring that the instructions for building something make sense and will result in what you want.

title: Lecture L13
body:
This lecture is about

  • different kinds of tools are available
  • a good process comes before a good tool
  • whatever the tool, its use must be fitting for the process
pageBody: Tool support for Requirements Engineering (RE) refers to the use of software tools designed to facilitate and enhance various aspects of the requirements management process. These tools assist in capturing, analyzing, documenting, and tracking requirements throughout the project lifecycle. They often provide requirements elicitation, traceability, version control, collaboration, and visualization, contributing to increased efficiency, accuracy, and collaboration within the RE process.

title: Lecture 09
body:
This lecture is about:

  • coloured Petri Nets (including mapping from AOM)
  • four variable model
  • other specification techniques that might be suitable for projects
pageBody: Welcome to our in-depth exploration of "Documentation" as part of the Requirements Engineering process. We will have four lectures (L06 - L09) to discuss the importance of the documentation step, its different steps, and the tools and models available to help you during this process.

title: Introduction
body: In this lecture, you will learn why Requirements Engineering is essential for software and systems engineers, get an overview of it, and learn about the different steps of the process.
pageBody: Discover the importance of Requirements Engineering, gain a broad understanding of it, and explore its key steps tailored for software and systems engineers.

title: System Context Boundaries and Types of Requirements
displayTitle: System Context Boundaries and Types of Requirements
body: In this lecture, you will learn what differentiates systems and context, what different types of boundaries exist and why they are essential for the Requirements Engineering process.
pageBody: Distinguish between systems and their context, identify various boundary types, and understand their significance in the Requirements Engineering process.

title: Colored Petri Nets
body: Documentation models are frameworks or structures that systematically capture and communicate information about a system or a process. They play a crucial role in requirements and software engineering, as well as other fields where complex systems need to be conceptualized, analyzed, and communicated.
subtitle: Lecture L08
pageBody: This lecture will provide an introduction to documentation models (Colored Petri Nets), discuss the mapping of Agent-Oriented Modelling to Colored Petri Nets, and wrap up with a summary that combines all of these ideas for a thorough grasp of modelling techniques.

title: Elicitation I
body: Elicitation is the first and one of the most crucial steps during the Requirements Engineering process. Part 1 gives a general overview of the elicitation process and introduces some techniques.
pageBody: This first part lays the foundation of the elicitation process, equipping you with practical tools and methodologies to define project requirements efficiently.

title: Elicitation II
body: In part 2 of the lecture on Requirements Elicitation, you will be introduced to some additional techniques to elicit information and get a summary of the whole process.
pageBody: This second part will delve into advanced techniques for gathering essential requirements and setting a solid foundation for a successful project outcome.

title: Negotiation
body: In this chapter, we will delve into the conflicts between stakeholders, explore possible conflicts, and discuss how these can be resolved using various techniques.
pageBody: In the negotiation phase, all stakeholders must gain a shared understanding of the requirements, and conflict management is essential to this process.

title: Documentation - Introduction
body: In this part of the lecture, we will focus on the foundations of documentation, including the documents' overall structure, practical templates, and well-defined requirements.
pageBody: This lecture introduces documentation fundamentals, including criteria for well-defined requirements, document structure, and document template usage.

title: Documentation - Textual Requirements Specification
body: This part of the lecture on documentation covers the intricacies of textual requirements specification. We will look at the challenges caused by ambiguity in requirements, address the vital role of established guidelines in resolving these challenges, as well as various syntactic requirements patterns that support the creation of clear and concise documentation.
pageBody: We explore the intricacies of textual requirements specification, addressing ambiguity issues, and examining syntactic patterns to ensure clear and precise documentation.

title: Documentation - Model-based Requirements Documentation
body: Documentation models are frameworks or structures used to systematically capture and communicate information about a system or a process.  They play a crucial role in requirements and software engineering, and other fields where complex systems need to be conceptualized, analyzed, and communicated.
pageBody: Documentation models serve as structured frameworks that systematically capture and convey information about systems or processes.

title: Documentation - Formal Requirements Specification
body: Modern system analysis and design are based on written formal requirements specification. Learn how to turn complicated processes into manageable models using tools like coloured Petri Nets and AOM -> CPN mapping. These approaches play a key role in software engineering and requirement analysis, where complex conceptualization is required.
pageBody: We explore the intricacies of formal requirements specification, addressing tools and frameworks that provide insights about ensuring system functioning and reliability.

title: Requirements validation
body: The validation steps of the Requirements Engineering process ensure that the implemented requirements are consistent with and meet the stakeholder's needs.
pageBody: The validation steps in the Requirements Engineering process guarantee that the implemented requirements satisfy the needs of the stakeholders.

title: Requirements Management
body: Change management is a systematic process within project management that entails evaluating, implementing, and controlling alterations to a project's scope, requirements, or objectives.
pageBody: Change management systematically evaluates, implements, and controls project scope changes and requirements.

title: Requirements Traceability
body: Tracing requirements allows you to analyse and understand the relations among requirements, requirements sources and development artefacts.
pageBody: Tracing requirements allows you to analyse and understand the relations among requirements, requirements sources and development artefacts.

title: Tool Support
body: Tool support for Requirements Engineering refers to the use of software tools designed to facilitate and enhance various aspects of the requirements management process.
pageBody: Tool support for Requirements Engineering refers to software tools designed to facilitate and enhance various aspects of the requirements management process.
